Item 10 regarding our Code of Business Conduct and Ethics is incorporated . Item 10 regarding the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee and the Audit Committee .
 The information required under this Item 12 is incorporated by reference to the information in the 2025 Proxy Statement under the captions “Equity Compensation Plan Information,” “Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners’s and Management and Related Stockholder Matters” The following Consolidated Financial Statements of Assurant, Inc. are attached hereto .
 The following Consolidated Financial Statement Schedules of Assurant, Inc. are attached hereto . The following exhibits either (a) are filed with this Report or (b) have previously been filed with the SEC and are incorporated herein by reference to those prior filings . The exhibits include: Exhibit 2.1 to the Registrant’s Current Report on Form 8-K, originally filed on January 9, 2018 .
 Assurant, Inc., TWG Holdings Limited, TWG Re, Ltd and Spartan Merger Sub, Ltd. (incorporated by reference from Exhibit 2.2 to the Registrant’s Current Report on Form 8-K, originally filed on May 31, 2018).  The Registrant hereby agrees to furnish to the SEC, upon request, a copy of any other instrument defining the rights of holders of long-term debt of the Registrant and its subsidiaries . The registrant’s Securities and Exchange Disclosure Disclosure Agreement is subject to the terms of the agreement and the disclosure required by the SEC .
 The Assurant, Inc. 2017 Long Term Equity Incentive Plan, as amended and restated as of November 8, 2023 (incorporated by reference from Exhibit 10.10 to the Registrant’s Annual Report on Form 10-K, originally filed on February 15, 2024)  .

 Amended and Restated Directors Compensation Plan, effective as of May 11, 2023 (incorporated by reference from Exhibit 10.1 to the Registrant’s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q, originally filed on May 5, 2022). *                10.21: Amendment No. 1 to the Assurant Executive 401(k) Plan, as amended and restated .
 The Registrant's Compensation Clawback Policy, effective as of October 2, 2023 (incorporated by reference from Exhibit 10.2 to the Registrant’s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q, originally filed on May 4, 20 23). The Company has a compensation clawback policy effective as well as an insider trading policy . The Company also has a power of attorney .
 The following materials from the Company’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2024, formatted in XBRL (Extensible Business Reporting Language): (i) the Consolidated Balance Sheets, (ii), (ii) the  Consolidated Statements of Operations, (iii) the consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income, (iv) and (v) the Statements of Changes in Stockholders’ Equity, (vi) Notes to the consolidated Financial Statements) Portions of this exhibit have been redacted in compliance with Regulation S-K Item 601(b)(10)(iv).
 The Board of Directors and Stockholders of Assurant, Inc. audited the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects .
 The Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the COSO . We are a public accounting firm registered with the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB) We are required to be independent with respect to the U.S. federal securities laws and the applicable rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the PCAOB .
 A company’s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles . We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions, and that the company's policies and procedures that (i) pertain to maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company .
 Internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements . Internal controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate . The communication of critical audit matters does not alter in any way our opinion on the consolidated financial statements, taken as a whole, and we are not providing a separate opinion .
 As of December 31, 2024, the Company’s total liability for claims and benefits payable was $2.91 billion, which included $2 .61 billion of liabilities for short duration contracts within the Global Lifestyle and Global Housing reporting segments . Claims and benefits payments are case reserves for known claims which are unpaid as of the balance sheet date . Loss adjustment expense reserves for the expected handling costs of settling the claims .
 PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP LLP has served as the Company’s auditor since 2000 . We have reviewed the effectiveness of controls relating to the valuation of claims and benefits payable reserves for short duration insurance contracts . We also reviewed the completeness and accuracy of historical claims data provided by management and the involvement of professionals with specialized skill .

 The amount of common shares used in diluted per common share calculations is based on the share price of $52,581,102 per share . The company's net losses are based on net unrealized gains on securities, net of taxes of $1.7.7, $2.3.7 and $1,695.7 . The Company's net loss is $7.2 million .

 The insurer's operating assets and liabilities include:Insurance policy reserves and expenses, expenses, accounts receivable, liabilities, liabilities and liabilities . The company's net realized losses on investments, including impairment losses, are estimated at $1,192.2 billion . The net cash provided by operating activities is prepared by investing activities withholding costs and other liabilities .
 The company acquired American Lease Insurance Agency Corporation (“ALI), net of $4.8.8 million of cash acquired . Cash and cash equivalents at beginning of period: $1,627.4.4-$1,536.7$1,807.7/7/10/12/20 .
 Assurant, Inc. is a leading global protection company that safeguards and services major consumer purchases through data-driven, technology solutions . The Company operates in North America, Latin America, Europe and Asia Pacific through two operating segments: Global Lifestyle and Global Housing . Through its Global Housing segment, the Company provides lender-placed homeowners, manufactured housing and flood insurance .
 The Company’s common stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol “AIZ.” The Consolidated Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“GAAP”) Dollars . Amounts are presented in U.S. dollars and all amounts are in millions .
 The Company believes all amounts reported are reasonable and adequate . Actual results could differ from the estimates recorded . The Company uses an exit price for its fair value measurements . The estimates are sensitive to market conditions, investment yields, mortality and mortality, mortality, morbidity, commissions and other acquisition expenses, policyholder behavior and other factors .
 Beginning July 1, 2018, as a result of the classification of Argentina’s economy as highly inflationary, the functional currency of our Argentina subsidiaries was changed from the local currency to U.S. dollars . The Company does not anticipate the ongoing remeasurement to have a material impact on the Company's results of operations or financial condition .
 The Company only holds non-consolidated VIEs as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 . Fixed maturity securities are classified as available-for-sale as defined in the investments guidance and are reported at fair value . If the fair value is higher than the amortized cost for fixed maturity securities, the excess is an unrealized gain .
 The allowance for credit losses is limited to the amount by which fair value is less than the amortized cost basis . For fixed maturities where the Company records a credit loss, a determination is made as to the cause of the impairment and whether the Company expects a recovery in the value . Write-offs are charged against the allowance when management concludes the financial asset is uncollectible .
 The Company reports receivables for accrued investment income separately from fixed maturities available for sale . The Company has certain equity investments that do not have readily determinable fair values . Changes in fair value recognized in net realized gains (losses) on investments and fair value changes to equity securities on the Company’s consolidated statements of operations .
 Commercial mortgage loans on real estate are reported at unpaid principal balances, adjusted for amortization of premium or discount, less any allowance for credit losses . The allowance for commercial mortgage loans is based on the present value of expected future cash flows discounted at the loan’s effective interest rate . The Company places loans on nonaccrual status after 90 days of delinquent payments (unless the loans are secured and in the process of collection)
 Other investments consist primarily of investments in joint ventures, partnerships, equity investments that do not have readily determinable fair values . These amounts are reported at cost or amortized cost, which approximates fair value . Realized gains and losses on sales of investments are recognized on the specific identification basis . The Company uses the interest method to recognize interest income on its commercial mortgage loans .
 The Company considers all highly liquid securities and other investments with durations of three months or less between the date of purchase and maturity to be cash equivalents . Cash balances are reviewed at the end of each reporting period to determine if negative cash balances exist . Negative cash balances are netted with other positive cash accounts of the same bank provided the right of offset exists .
 Cost of reinsurance is recognized as a reduction to premiums earned over the terms of the underlying reinsured policies . Amounts recoverable from reinsurers are estimated in a manner consistent with claim and claim adjustment expense reserves or future policy benefits reserves . Reinsurers typically hold collateral (in the form of funds withheld, trusts and letters of credit) as security under the reinsurance agreements . The Company uses a probability of default and loss given default methodology in estimating the allowance .
 The methodology used by the Company incorporates historical default factors for each reinsurer based on their credit rating using comparably rated bonds as published by a major ratings service . The allowance is based upon the Company’s ongoing review of amounts outstanding, length of collection periods, changes in reinsurer credit standing and other relevant factors .
 Only direct and incremental costs associated with new or renewal contracts are deferred to the extent that such costs are deemed acceptable . If the premium deficiency is greater than unamortized, a loss (and related) is recorded for the excess . All other acquisition-related costs, including those related to market training, are expensed as incurred .
 Depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis over estimated useful lives . Property and equipment are assessed for impairment when impairment indicators exist . Goodwill represents the excess of acquisition costs over the net fair value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination . Device protection, credit insurance, lender-placed homeowners insurance and flood, multifamily housing and manufactured housing insurance are amortized .
 Goodwill is tested for impairment at the reporting unit level, which is either at the operating segment or one level below . The evaluation of such factors requires considerable management judgment . If the Company’s estimated fair value exceeds its net book value, goodwill is deemed not to be impaired . The Company has the option to first assess qualitative factors to determine whether it is necessary to perform a quantitative goodwill impairment test .
 Estimated useful lives of finite intangible assets are required to be reassessed on at least an annual basis . For intangible assets with finite lives, impairment is recognized if the carrying amount is not recoverable and exceeds the fair value of the other intangible asset . For vehicle service contracts and extended service contracts, VOBA is amortized consistent with premium earning patterns of the underlying in-force contracts .
 Amortization expense and impairment charges for other intangible assets are included in underwriting, selling, general and administrative expenses in the consolidated statements of operations . Reserves are established using generally accepted actuarial methods and reflect judgments about expected future premium and claim payments . Factors used in their calculation include experience derived from historical claim payments, expected future premiums and actuarial assumptions .
 There can be no certainty that future settlement amounts for claims incurred through the financial reporting date will not vary from reported claims reserves . Future loss development could require reserves to be increased or decreased, which could have a material effect on the Company’s earnings in the periods in which such increases or decreases are made . The Company believes its reserve estimates are adequate .
 Certain businesses which the Company expects to fully exit, including the long-tail commercial liability businesses (sharing economy and small commercial businesses), certain legacy long-duration insurance policies and the Company’s operations in mainland China . During 2024, the mainland China operations were sold and will no longer be included in non-core operations going forward .
 Policy expense assumptions locked in as of December 31, 2020 as the long-term care insurance products are in run-off as of the transition date . Actual premiums and benefits are recognized on a quarterly basis in the consolidated statement of operations allocated in proportion to prior period cash flow projections at the cohort level . The difference between the updated future policy benefits and expenses reserve opening period and previous ending period due to updating the NPR is presented as a remeasurement gain or loss in policyholder benefits .
 The long-term care insurance contracts are fully reinsured and there is no impact to consolidated stockholders’ equity or net income . Short duration contracts include products and services in the Global Lifestyle and Global Housing segments . For short duration contracts, claims and benefits payable reserves are recorded when insured events occur . The liability is based on the expected ultimate cost of settling .
 The claims and benefits payable reserves include (1) case reserves for known but unpaid claims as of the balance sheet date . (2) incurred but not reported (“IBNR”) reserves for claims where the insured event has occurred but has not been reported to the Company . (3) loss adjustment expense reserves for the expected handling costs of settling the claims .
 The Company reports debt net of acquisition costs, unamortized discount or premium and repurchases . Interest expense related to debt is expensed as incurred . The Company accounts for credit losses using the expected credit loss model for high deductible recoverables . The allowance is based upon the Company’s ongoing review of amounts outstanding, length of collection periods, changes in insured credit standing .
 The Company accounts for the retirement of repurchased shares using the par value method . When the repurchase price of the shares is greater than the original issue proceeds, the excess is charged to retained earnings . The Company’s short duration contracts revenue is recognized over the contract term in proportion to the amount of insurance protection provided .
 The Company derives fees and other income from providing administrative services, mobile-related services and mortgage property risk management services . The Company reports revenues related to long duration and short duration insurance contracts as premiums, including insurance contracts written by non-insurance affiliates, consistent with the Company’s principal business of insurance . The unexpired portion of fee revenues are deferred and amortized over the term of the contracts .
 Current federal income taxes are recognized based upon amounts estimated to be payable or recoverable as a result of taxable operations for the current year . Deferred income taxes recorded for temporary differences between the financial reporting basis and income tax basis of assets and liabilities . The Company classifies net interest expense related to tax matters and any applicable penalties as a component of income tax expense .
 The Company and its subsidiaries lease office space and equipment under operating lease arrangements for which the Company is the lessee . The Company records expenses for operating leases on a straight-line basis over the lease term . Changes to GAAP are established by the Financial Accounting Standards Board in the form of Accounting Standards Updates (“ASUs”) to the FASB Accounting Standards Codification .
 The guidance is applied retrospectively to all periods presented in the financial statements, unless it is impracticable . The Company adopted the standard as of December 31, 2024 and the amended segment information disclosures is presented in Note 5 . The guidance applies retrospectively, unless the Company adopts the standard in the future .
 The Company is assessing the adoption of this standard as of January 1, 2025 (with early adoption permitted) The amended guidance is expected to have no impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statements and insignificant impact on income tax disclosures . ASUs not listed below were assessed and either determined to be not applicable or not expected to impact the Company's financial statements or disclosures .
 The Company is assessing the impact of adopting this standard as of December 31, 2027 . The amended guidance is expected to have no impact on the Company’s consolidated financial statements and to expand the annual and interim disclosures of disaggregation of relevant expense captions . The total allowance for credit losses for the financial assets was $20.7.7% and $26.8% as of Dec. 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively .
 Reinsurance is used to mitigate certain risks underwritten by various business segments . The Company is exposed to the credit risk of reinsurers, as the Company remains liable to insureds regardless of whether related reinsurance recoverables are collected . As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, reinsurance recoverable recoverables totaled $7.58-58 billion and $6.65-65 billion, respectively .
 The allowance may be increased and income reduced in future periods if there are future ratings downgrades or other measurable information supporting an increase in reinsurer default probabilities, including collateral reductions . When determining the allowance as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Company did not increase default probabilities by reinsurer since there had been no credit rating downgrades .
 For the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, the current period change for credit losses was $2.9 million, primarily due to an increase in Global Lifestyle across various products . There is a risk that income may be reduced in future periods for additional credit losses . The Company reduced its allowance for credit loss for the unsecured portion of the high deductible portion of high deductible recoverables by $6.9 million to $1.4 million .
 As of December 31, 2024, the Company had two reportable operating segments: Global Lifestyle and Global Housing . The Company defines Adjusted EBITDA, the segment measure of profitability, as net income, excluding net realized gains (losses) on investments, non-core operations, restructuring costs related to strategic exit activities . Assurant Health runoff operations (described below) are described below .
 The following table presents segment Adjusted EBITDA with a reconciliation to net income . The Company's net investment income was $4,259.4 . Revenues were $9,323.9.9 and $1,958.9 for global housing, automotive, mortgage, insurance, insurance and other expenses .
 The Company has fully exited or expects to fully exit certain businesses, including the mainland China operations, certain legacy long-duration insurance policies and the Company’s operations in mainland China . The non-core operations do not qualify as held for sale or discontinued operations under GAAP accounting guidance and are presented as a reconciling item to consolidated net income . Refer to Note 14 for additional information .
 The Company principally operates in the U.S., as well as Europe, Latin America, Canada and Asia Pacific .  The Company also repairs, refurbishes and then sells mobile and other electronic devices, on behalf of its client, for a bundled per unit fee . Each service is an individual performance obligation with a standalone selling price . The Company recognizes revenue as it invoices, which corresponds to the value transferred to the customer .
 The Company defers upfront commissions and other costs in connection with client contracts in excess of one year where the Company can demonstrate future economic benefit .  The Company concluded that for these securities, the gross unrealized losses as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 were related to non-credit factors and therefore did not recognize credit-related losses . The Company currently does not intend to and is not required to sell these investments prior to an anti-trust resolution .

 As of December 31, 2024, the Company had mortgage loan commitments outstanding of approximately $6.4 million . The fair value of the underlying commercial properties is updated at least annually . The Company had short-term investments and fixed maturity securities of $.636.1 million and $.69.0 million as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 .
 The Company invests in real estate joint ventures and limited partnerships, as well as closed ended real estate funds . As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Company’s maximum exposure to loss is its recorded carrying value of $281.2 million and $269.1 million . The Company's unfunded commitments were $.-239.2-million as of December 31, 2024. The Company has categorized its recurring fair value basis financial assets and liabilities .
 The fair value hierarchy within which the fair value measurement in its entirety falls has been determined based on the lowest level input . Level 1 inputs utilize quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the Company can access . Level 2 inputs utilize other than quoted prices included in Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the asset . Level 3 inputs reflect management’s own assumptions about the assumptions a market participant would use in pricing .
 The amounts presented below for short-term investments, other investments, cash equivalents, other assets, assets held in and liabilities related to separate accounts differ from the amounts presented in the consolidated balance sheets . Other investments are comprised of investments in the AIP, the ASIC plan, and the ADC and other derivatives . The fair value amount and the majority of the associated levels presented for other investments and assets and liabilities held in separate accounts are received directly from third parties .
 Financial assets: $9,030.0,030,$1,633.9,000,$7,205.4,$2.6,190,$770,700,000 . $1,8,485,000 (1,532,000)  Financial Liabilities: $7.079.0/1,051.3/1.4/2.5/3/2/4/5/6/8/9/10/11/12/13/14/13: $7,079/1/14: $770,000/8,000; $1.5,000-1,000.00/1
 The following tables summarize the change in balance sheet carrying value associated with Level 3 financial assets and liabilities carried at fair value for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023: The tables are based on the information provided by the company . The financial balance sheets are shown below: The following table: The financial statements are presented at the bottom of the table .
 Three different valuation techniques can be used in determining fair value for financial assets and liabilities: the market, income or cost approaches . The three valuation techniques described in the fair value measurements and disclosures guidance are consistent with generally accepted valuation methodologies . The market approach valuation techniques use prices and other relevant information generated by market transactions involving identical or comparable assets or liabilities .
 The Company’s investments and liabilities classified as Level 1 as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 consisted of mutual funds and related obligations, money market funds and common stocks that are publicly listed and/or actively traded in an established market . The Company values Level 2 securities using various observable market inputs obtained from a pricing method . For all the classes of financial assets and liabilities included in the above hierarchy, the Company generally uses the market valuation technique .
 The fair value measurements and disclosures guidance defines observable market inputs as the assumptions market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability developed on market data obtained from sources independent of the Company . The extent of the use of each observable market input for a security depends on the type of security and the market conditions at the balance sheet date .
 The pricing service evaluates each security based on relevant market information including relevant credit information, perceived market movements and sector news . Foreign government securities are primarily fixed maturity securities denominated in local currencies . Non-investment grade securities within this category are priced by the Company’s pricing service and asset managers using observations of equity and credit default swap curves related to the issuer .
 The Company’s investments classified as Level 3 as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 consisted of $184.3705 million and $125.5.5 million of fixed maturity and equity securities . The Company prices options using non-binding quotes provided by market makers or broker dealers . Foreign exchange forwards are priced using a pricing model which utilizes market observable inputs .
 The Company generally obtains one price for each financial asset . Illiquidity did not have a material impact in the fair value determination of the Company’s financial assets as of December 31, 2024 or 2023 . The Company performs a periodic analysis to assess if the evaluated prices represent a reasonable estimate of the financial assets’ fair values . This process involves quantitative and qualitative analysis and is overseen by investment and accounting professionals .
 In 2024 and 2023, as a result of third-party market observable transactions that were of the same issuer and determined to be similar, the Company marked certain of its equity investments accounted for under the measurement alternative to fair value . These valuations utilize the market approach, or an option pricing model backsolve method, which can be used to determine the value of common shares for companies with complex capital structures .
 Guidance requires disclosure of fair value information about financial instruments that are not recognized or are not carried at fair value in the consolidated balance sheets . Guidance excludes certain financial instruments, including those related to insurance contracts and those accounted for under the equity method . For the financial instruments included within the following financial assets and financial liabilities, the carrying value in those assets equals or approximates fair value .
 The fair value of commercial mortgage loans on real estate utilizes a third-party matrix pricing model . Other investments include low income housing tax credits, business debentures, and credit tenant loans which are recorded at cost or amortized cost, as well as policy loans . The carrying value of dealer loans approximates fair value due to the short maturity of the instruments .
 The fair value of the Company’s policy reserves for investment-type contracts (those without significant mortality or morbidity risk) are reflected in the tables above .  The components of income tax expense (benefit) were as follows for the periods indicated . The provision for foreign taxes includes amounts attributable to income from U.S. possessions that are considered foreign under tax laws . International operations of the Company are subject to income taxes imposed by the jurisdiction in which they operate . The Company’s effective income tax rate is 18.0-20.0% .
 Results for 2024, 2023, and 2022 primarily include the impact of foreign earnings taxed at different rates . Results are primarily related to a foreign derived intangible income benefit of $9.2.2 million taken on an amended 2019 income tax return . Amounts owed to counterparties for the purchased credits are recorded within accounts payable and accrued expenses within the consolidated balance sheet at December 31, 2024 .
 The Company’s continuing practice is to recognize interest expense related to income tax matters in income tax expense . The liability for unrecognized tax benefits is included in accounts payable and other liabilities on the consolidated balance sheets . The Company and its subsidiaries file income tax returns in the U.S. and various state and foreign jurisdictions .
 The Company’s ability to realize deferred tax assets depends on its ability to generate sufficient taxable income of the same character within the carryback or carryforward periods . Under current U.S. tax law, no material income taxes are anticipated on future repatriation of earnings . The Company plans to indefinitely reinvest the earnings in other jurisdictions .
 Net operating loss carryforwards by jurisdiction are as follows as of December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2023 . $19.8% expires between 2025 and 2044, $.9% has an unlimited carryforward . $9,967.2/2022: Deferred Acquisition Costs $9,992.8/2023: depreciation expense for the years ended December 31 .
 During first quarter 2025, the Company entered into an agreement to sell the Miami, Florida property to a buyer for a purchase price of $126.0 million . The Company expects to record a gain above the carrying value, less estimated costs to sell . There can be no assurance that the transaction will be consummated .
 A Dividend Discount Method (“DDM”) was used to value each of the reporting units based upon the present value of expected cash flows available for distribution over future periods . Cash flows were estimated for a discrete projection period based on detailed assumptions, and a terminal value was calculated to reflect the value attributable to cash flows beyond the discrete period .
 In the second quarter of 2022, $7.8 million of goodwill was allocated to the sharing economy and small commercial businesses which are included within non-core operations in Corporate and Other . The fair value of the  sharing economy was determined using a discounted cash flow method . The Company concluded that the estimated fair values of the Connected Living, Global Automotive and Global Housing reporting units exceeded their respective book values .
 The fair value calculated in the fourth quarter of 2022 was lower than the carrying value of the run-off businesses, resulting in the pre-tax and after-tax impairment charge of the entire goodwill of $7.8 million . The goodwill impairment charge was reported separately in the consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December 31, 2022 .
 As of December 31, 2024, the outstanding VOBA balance is primarily related to the 2018 acquisition of TWG within the Global Lifestyle segment . Purchased intangible assets primarily consist of contract based and customer related intangibles related to acquisitions over the past few years . The estimated amortization of VOBA for the next five years and thereafter is as follows .
 The Company’s short duration contracts include products and services within the Global Lifestyle and Global Housing segments . The main product lines for Global Housing include lender-placed homeowners, manufactured housing and flood insurance; voluntary manufactured housing, condominium and homeowners insurance; and renters insurance . The estimated amortization of other intangible assets with finite lives for the next five years and thereafter is as follows: Purchased Intangible Assets. The estimated loss and loss adjustment expenses are estimated utilizing generally accepted actuarial loss reserving methods .
 Reportable catastrophe losses are analyzed and reserved for separately using a frequency and severity approach . The Munich Chain Ladder method takes into account the correlations between paid and incurred development in projecting future development factors . The Bornhuetter-Ferguson method employs a combination of past claims development and an estimate of ultimate losses based on an expected loss ratio .

 Interest expense includes derivative related activities described in the interest rate derivatives section below . Interest on the 2026 Senior Notes is payable semi-annually in arrears on February 27 and August 27 of each year, beginning on August 27, 2023 . The Company issued senior notes due February 2026 with an aggregate principal amount of $175.0.0676 million, which bear interest at a rate of 6.10% per year and were issued at a 0.035% discount to the public .
 In August 2019, the Company issued senior notes with an aggregate principal amount of $350.0.0-a-year interest . Interest is payable semi-annually in arrears on January 15 and July 15 of each year . Prior to October 15, 2031 the Company may redeem the 2032 Senior Notes at any time in whole or from time to time in part at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount being redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest .
 In March 2023 and June 2022, the Company redeemed $.175.0%-0.0% of the then outstanding aggregate principal amount of the 2023 Senior Notes at a make-whole premium plus accrued and unpaid interest to the redemption date . The Company recognized a gain (loss) on extinguishment of debt of $.1.-1.1% and $.9% for the years ended December 31, 2023 . Interest on the 2028 Senior Notes is payable semi-annually . The interest rate on each of the notes is subject to adjustment from time to time .
 The Company issued senior notes with an aggregate principal amount of $.475.0.0-million at a .61-0.61% discount to the public, which bear interest at .6.75% per year and matures in February 2034 . These senior notes are not redeemable prior to maturity . The Company may redeem the 2061 Subordinated Notes in whole at any time or in part from time to time .
 In March 2018, the Company issued fixed-to-floating rate subordinated notes due March 2048 with principal amount of $400.0 million . The 2048 Subordinated Notes bear interest from March 2018 to March 2028 at an annual rate of                 7.00%, payable semi-annually . Under the terms of the debt agreement, a substitute or successor base rate will be used since the LIBOR base rate has been discontinued .
 The Company has the right to defer the payment of interest on the Subordinated Notes for one or more consecutive interest periods for up to five years . Interest will continue to accrue at the then-applicable interest rate . At any time when the Company has given notice of its election to defer interest payments, the Company generally may not make payments on or redeem or purchase any shares of the Company’s capital stock .
 The Company’s commercial paper program requires the Company to maintain liquidity facilities in an available amount equal to any outstanding notes from the program or in an amount sufficient to maintain the ratings assigned to the notes . The Company's commercial paper is rated AMB-1+ by A.M. Best, P-2 by Moody's and S&P . The company's subsidiaries do not maintain commercial paper or other borrowing facilities . The Credit Facility contains restrictive covenants .
 The Company entered into derivative transactions to hedge the risk associated with changes in interest rates in anticipation of debt issuances . The Company determined that the derivatives qualified for hedge accounting as effective cash flow hedges and recognized deferred gains upon settlement . The deferred gains are recognized as a reduction in interest expense related to the 2026 Senior Notes, the 2028 Senior Notes and the 2048 Subordinated Notes on an effective yield basis . The amortization of the deferred gain was $2.7 million, $.8.8 million and $.3.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2024, 2023 and 2022 .
 The Assurant, Inc. is authorized to repurchase up to $20.0-$600.0 million aggregate cost at purchase of its outstanding common stock . The timing and amount of future repurchases will depend on market conditions, the Company’s financial condition, results of operations and liquidity and other factors .
 Under the ALTEIP, the Company may grant awards based on shares of its common stock, including stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock (including performance shares) and restricted stock units (“RSUs”), performance units (also known as performance share units) and dividend equivalents . The fair value of RSUs is estimated using the fair market value of a share of the Company’s common stock .
 The number of shares of common stock a participant will receive upon vesting of a PSU award is contingent upon the Company’s performance with respect to selected metrics, as identified below . PSUs accrue dividend equivalents during the performance period based on a target payout amount . The payout levels can vary between  conservative0.0% and conservative200% of the target (100%) ALTEIP award amount .
 The Compensation Committee has established  two equally weighted performance measures for PSU awards:  Total shareholder return relative to the S&P 500 Index (“market condition”), defined as appreciation in the Company’s common stock plus dividend yield to stockholders . The total fair value of PSUs vested was $39.8.8 million,    and will be paid in cash at the end of the performance period based on the actual number of shares issued .
 The fair value of the performance condition was estimated using the fair market value of a share of the Company’s common stock at the date of grant . Expected volatilities were based on the historical prices of the company's common stock and peer group, the expected term was assumed to equal the average of the vesting period of the PSUs . The risk-free rate was based on  the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant. Expected volatility was estimated at 25.76%. Expected term (years)
 Employee Stock Purchase Plan allows employees to contribute portions of their after-tax compensation toward the purchase of shares of the Company’s common stock . There are two offering periods during the year (January 1 through June 30 and July 1 through December 31) and shares of common stock are purchased at the end of each offering period at  the lower of the closing price of the common stock on the first or last day of the offering period . Participants’ contributions are limited to a maximum contribution of $7.5.5.,000,000 thousand per offering period or $15.0395,000 per year .
 The fair value of each award under the ESPP was estimated at the beginning of each offering period using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model and assumptions in the table below . Expected volatilities are based on implied volatabilities from traded options on the Company’s common stock and the historical volatility of the Company's common stock . The risk-free rate for periods within the contractual life of the option is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect at the time of grant .
 The ADC Plan was established in order to comply with the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 . The ADC provides key employees the ability to defer a portion of their eligible compensation to be notionally invested in a variety of mutual funds . Deferrals and withdrawals under the ADC are intended to be fully compliant with the Jobs Act definition of eligible compensation and distribution requirements .

 The payment of dividends to the Company by any of the Company’s regulated U.S. domiciled insurance subsidiaries in excess of a certain amount (i.e., extraordinary dividends) must be approved by the subsidiary's domiciliary jurisdiction department of insurance . Ordinary dividends, for which no regulatory approval is generally required, are limited to amounts determined by a formula .
 The maximum amount of dividends that the Company’s U.S. domiciled insurance subsidiaries could pay to the Company in 2025 without regulatory approval is approximately $395 million . No assurance can be given that there will not be further regulatory actions restricting the ability of the Company's insurance subsidiaries to pay dividends .
